10504: Empty City Ruse.text_parsed: The current card text further clarifies what this card is supposed to do.  Great addition to a few instant spells of the similar or identical kind.  A sorcery spell for 1 mana, you get to “prevent” by denying your opponent a combat phase next turn: great bargain, 5 stars.  Sure, I’d agree that an instant spell of identical effect would probably be the best case scenario, but there’s not too much difference in the timing/execution of either instant or sorcery for this effect.  The artwork reminds me of some of the older styles of its kind.  Ah, remember the storylines back then (flavour text).

10506: Zodiac Rooster.author: Zetan
10506: Zodiac Rooster.text_parsed:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

10515: Imperial Edict.author: NobuTheBard
10515: Imperial Edict.text_parsed:
Sacrifice didn't appear as a mechanic in Portal Three Kingdoms, that is why it is destroyed instead of sacrificed. All those that have it now from the set (Xiahou Dun, the One-Eyed, Fire Bowman, and Loyal Retainers) had their official text changed only later, and make no references to sacrifice on the printed cards.

The three Portal sets each used a more restrictive vocabulary to try to introduce the game to new players.

10521: Overwhelming Forces.author: mdakw576
10521: Overwhelming Forces.text_parsed:
Baneslayer is not broken. It's just very, very good, but it's going to drop in price once it rotates out of standard. Broken would be something like tarmogoyf or force of will, or banned/restricted cards like tolarian academy.

In general, anything that costs a lot of mana (especially 8) is not going to be broken. Exceptions would be cards that instantly win you the game once it's played regardless of the situation, like yawgmoth's bargain or mind's desire. This will more or less instantly win you the game, but only if your opponent is running lots of creatures. Most legacy and vintage decks don't even run many creatures.

However, I can easily expect this to be a house in casual or longer games like EDH.

10521: Overwhelming Forces.author: Paladin85
10521: Overwhelming Forces.text_parsed:
Anyone who is put off by the supposedly high mana cost should consider:

1) Wrath of God / Damnation are both 4 mana CMC

2) This is one sided board wipe: +2 CMC

3) Draw cards for each creature destroyed: +2 CMC

It is not broken with its high mana cost and you probably wouldn't want to waste it on just a big indestructible fattie (unless its something like Blightsteel Colossus). This card is well costed considering the number of good things it does for you

A functional reprint that prevents regeneration would probably see some play in EDH and casual and maybe in some constructed decks

10521: Overwhelming Forces.author: CorkBulb
10521: Overwhelming Forces.text_parsed:
WHAT! OMG. This is what "random card" leads me to discover.

This has GOT to be the best two-player black board wipe available! AND it's one sided AND gives you huge card advantage!!!! The card advantage from this plus the one-sided board wipe is most likely going to win you the game. If you frag even 3 creatures with this, the advantage is huge.

Generally, drawing large amounts of cards is a good thing, unless you are milling yourself to death, or being milled yourself!

Plague Wind is better in multiplayer as a board wipe, since it kills *all* your opponents' creatures. Generally, I stick to two player. Multiplayer is just too slow for me. And I *hate it* when everybody gangs up on me (mostly because they all know I run stuff like this!)

5/5 excellent black destruction

10525: Zhou Yu, Chief Commander.author: mrchuckmorris
10525: Zhou Yu, Chief Commander.text_parsed:
ZY: "I, the mighty Zhou Yu, challenge you to a battle, Kongming!" *punches wall into a thousand pieces*

KM: "Uh, but... well you see, Mr. Yu... I don't have a private island!"

ZY: "What is this nonsense?!" *karate chops a leviathan in half*

KM: "Yup, too bad, I think it's in, like, the naval warfare rules or bushido or something. You can't attack me unless I have an Island. Sorry bro!"

ZY's first mate: "Dang, I think he's right, captain... we'll have to wait til he's on a ship or something..."

ZY: "SILENCE, FOOL!!!" *drop-kicks him into another dimension*

Wow, it's like Earthquake and Hurricane combined, or like a Savage Twister reduced by that damages each player as well.

Well basically it's an Earthquake Portal Three Kingdoms version since most creatures that would normally have flying come with Horsemanship instead.
Your big advantage: Your opponent most likely won't play any P3K cards while you can practically hit each creatures and maybe even spare some of yours if you're nerdy enough to play creatures with Horsemanship :D

By the way, this card has also a counterpart named Borrowing the East Wind, unfortunately you can imagine this one isn't really playable (except for block-constructed, of course) - it even costs two green mana to cast^^

10534: Zodiac Dog.author: Zetan
10534: Zodiac Dog.text_parsed:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

10538: Control of the Court.author: DacenOctavio
10538: Control of the Court.text_parsed:
That doesn't work with Sundial. You have to resolve all of the effects of the spell before anyone else gains priority. You can't end the turn to prevent the discard.

Instead, use Library of Leng so you can choose where the discarded cards go: in the graveyard where you won't have to draw them, or on top in case you wanted those cards. Replacement effects like that DO interfere with the effects of spells and abilities.

For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.
10540: Zodiac Goat.text_posted:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

As long as Diaochan and your major attacker are protected, go ahead and use her. Or you can play two-color and give all creatures you control shroud. Or play Diaochan in multiplayer and use her ability only when the opponent is more likely to choose another player's creature to kill then one of yours. After all, nowhere does it say the opponent who gets to destroy a creature has to be the one whose creature was destroyed.

She seems like a fine card, possibly even making Mono-Red EDH just-viable.
She's certainly welcome in all sorts of R/U/x builds.

They're reprinting her in Commander's Arsenal. I looked her up on SCG, and she doesn't seem very expensive for a Portal card, just incredibly rare. It looks to me like Commander's Arsenal won't exactly flop, but it with 7/10 Oversized cards spoiled as of this post, only Sliver Queen might raise eyebrows, and so far I can't find anyone but me interested in her. :(

And with 10/18 Normal-Sized cards known, it looks like Blue and Black have basically been given the shaft over Green, Red and White are getting Portal Cards, and other than Sylvan Library, Command Tower, and Silver Queen, the box is as good as From the Vault: Legends. Which isn't spectacular, just 'oh, these are nice to have in foil', plus Progenitus is decent value.

So can anyone tell me, does the announcement of a Foil, regular-sized Daiochan sound AMAZING to you, "Great, it's Foil and Modern Framed!" to you, or "Not any better than Chaos Warp" to you?

10545: Southern Elephant.author: Aaron_Forsythe
10545: Southern Elephant.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #19, 10/21/10

There is a bit of rambling I could do about how ill-equipped the design toolbox of Portal: Three Kindgoms was to attempt tackling a top-down set of such magnitude, but that doesn’t really apply to this card. Southern Elephant is a fine “design” in as much as it is as mundane as the creature it is representing.

Vanillas with interesting numbers do represent one of the finite—and most well-defined—areas of Magic design, so it always blows me away when we find one that hasn’t existed before. It took a very long time for a 4/3 to be put into a “real” set—Champions of Kamigawa’s Order of the Sacred Bell, a full fifteen years after Dr. Garfield clearly illustrated that green got better than Hill Giant at common on Day One (with War Mammoth).

The inverse of the Order—the Blanchwood Treefolk to its Spined Wurm—is this card, Southern Elephant, a card with a set of numbers that has yet to appear on a vanilla in a “real set.” Kind of mind-blowing, really. I think the card would be quite playable in limited and fits right in with even the most modern of common creature curves. I now have a new mission.

It’s interesting to note that the Portal sets did a decent job of exploring this vanilla territory. Southern Elephant’s stats first appeared on Rowan Treefolk in the original Portal, and Order of the Sacred Bell’s stats were first on Golden Bear from Portal: Second Age. That set also contained the better-than-Craw Wurm 6/4 Barbtooth Wurm, another card worth bringing to a “real” set someday.

10548: Cao Cao, Lord of Wei.author: DarthParallax
10548: Cao Cao, Lord of Wei.text_parsed:
I don't quite know enough about P3K, except that PK-421 isn't at his post.

Even so, just by rarity alone, any remotely useful card from Kingdoms justifies inclusion in a From the Vault set.

I think it might be a good idea for Wizards to make another special boxed set, not Premium Decks, not Commander or Archenemy, and not even From the Vault to get a lot more Portals cards into Black-Bordered English. Try like a thing the size of a booster box (540 cards) MSRP = $100, and a foil alternate art Xiahou-Dun, the One-Eyed can come automatically for Buy-A-Case Buyers.

They don't want to destroy the secondary market for cards- reprinting Xiahou-Dun, if it's done at all, needs to be done carefully so we don't repeat the Chronicles/Legends fiasco. It can be done, but not even in From the Vault, or any currently released product. Maybe something special for Gen Con one of these years? You can knock an UBER OMFG rare down to a Mythic Rare, but not down to uncommon. Not everyone will have a Xiahou-Dun, and that just needs to be lived with.

10549: Borrowing the East Wind.author: Binaro
10549: Borrowing the East Wind.text_parsed:
In case you guys are wondering about the flavor, this is about the time Zhuge Liang predicted the weather and used that to his advantage. Cao Cao wanted to invade some place, but he had no adequate naval soldiers and the best way to attack that place was to use ships, so he had to connect all the ships together so that his horsemen could ride with ease. However, because Zhuge Liang knew that the east wind was going to blow on the day of the battle, he prepared the soldiers to burn the ships. He told them that he "borrowed" the east wind through some weird ritual(because rituals that work will make people praise him). Because of the east wind, the fire spread really quickly from boat to boat, annihilating Cao Cao's forces(primarily composed of horsemen).
Honestly, this card isn't as bad as people condemn it to be. Green burn isn't that common. Even if it hoses something pretty much no one plays, it still burns players.

10552: Warrior's Oath.author: Bandswithother
10552: Warrior's Oath.text_parsed:
"To all wondering, Sundial of the Infinite does not save you from loosing the game, because you are ENDING the turn. It would work if this read: "at the end step of that turn..." or something similar." - flavioal28

This is flat out untrue. First lets look at the oracle text for this card (because that is the relavent rules text).

Take an extra turn after this one. At the beggining of that turns end step, you lose the game.

The bolded portion is setting up a delayed trigger at the end of that turn. When moving to the end step of that turn the trigger will go off and put the triggered ability on the stack saying you lose the game.

The only way spells and abilities can resolve on the stack is when all players pass priority without doing anything. So both you and your opponent get a chance to do something before you lose the game.

You can take this time to respond to the trigger by Acivating a Sundial of the Infinite, casting a Time stop, casting a Stifle, or casting a Trickbind.

Then, assuming your opponent has no answer, Sundial/ Time stop resolve, exiling everything on the stack (including the you lose trigger), or Stifle/ Trickbind counter the ability. Either way will cause your turn to end, and the game continues as normal.

The only way spells and abilities can resolve on the stack is when all players pass priority without doing anything. So both you and your opponent get a chance to do something before you lose the game.

You can take this time to respond to the trigger by Acivating a [autocard]Sundial of the Infinite[/autocard], casting a [autocard]Time stop[/autocard], casting a [autocard]Stifle[/autocard], or casting a [autocard]Trickbind[/autocard].

Then, assuming your opponent has no answer, Sundial/ Time stop resolve, exiling everything on the stack (including the you lose trigger), or Stifle/ Trickbind counter the ability.  Either way will cause your turn to end, and the game continues as normal.

10558: Zodiac Monkey.author: Zetan
10558: Zodiac Monkey.text_parsed:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

10565: Mystic Denial.author: Dumedag
10565: Mystic Denial.text_parsed:
I guess it was a sorcery because Portal was all about simplifying the game's rules.
Because that is what this does... Yeah, no. Not really.
There were no Instants, so when a card said what it did, well, that was what you had to do. This card here is bad, very bad, but this is during Magic's first years. They had already broken the game with über-like spells, so now they had to print this sad, strictly worse Counterspell. Don't blame them for trying to balance the game. (this doesn't stop me from giving the card a 1/5 though)

@Krypnyt
If I recall correctly, MaRo said in one of his numrous articles that if he could change the fundamental grounds of Magic, he would make the Instant type a supertype, such as Snow or Legendary.
This probably because (and if so, I totally agree) if he knew Flash would be such a big keyword it is today, it would be much cleaner to sum up the ability in a supertype rather than using up precious text box space for printing a keyword. Rather than a creature would have Flash, it would be an "Instant Creature — X Y". An instant would be, well, an "Instant Sorcery" I guess.

http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/mm/42
(the source, fifth question from the bottom)
Sorry about the rant, but I guess I had much to say about this card :)

10582: Zodiac Rabbit.author: Zetan
10582: Zodiac Rabbit.text_parsed:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

10588: Return to Battle.author: VDZx
10588: Return to Battle.text_parsed:
"Xiahou Dun lost his left eye when he was a hit by a stray arrow during a battle against Lü Bu in the late 190s, and subsequently became known among the rank and file as "Blind Xiahou", which greatly irked him. His image as a one-eyed warrior was later popularised by Luo Guanzhong's historical novel Romance of the Three Kingdoms, in which he yanked the arrow fired by enemy general Cao Xing out of his eye and devoured his own eyeball to instil fear in his enemies." -Wikipedia

There's your explanation for the eye swallowing.

10590: Xiahou Dun, the One-Eyed.author: kylenyu
10590: Xiahou Dun, the One-Eyed.text_parsed:
This is my mono black general, and people just hate this deck with a passion.

As for timing restrictions, it's actually not as restrictive as you may think. Any time before your combat step includes your Upkeep. A very common scenario will be sacrificing Xiahou during my upkeep to pull something crazy from my Graveyard, then just using Volrath's Stronghold to get him back during my draw step.

10594: Zodiac Tiger.author: Zetan
10594: Zodiac Tiger.text_parsed:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

10602: Strategic Planning.author: Madrai
10602: Strategic Planning.text_parsed: Ponder wasn't around in Portal the Third Age (My favorite set just because of flavor.) This card, while not amazing, gave you options back then, and options equal advantage usually. Portal was beginners magic, no interrupts (Sorry, Instants.), less dealing with the stack, more about smashing your opponent's face in battle. Was it an amazing set? No, it's noobish and beginner, even back then, but the flavor of it still sparks my love of Magic. Plus Horsemanship.

10608: Zodiac Snake.author: Zetan
10608: Zodiac Snake.text_parsed:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

10619: Capture of Jingzhou.author: Smauls
10619: Capture of Jingzhou.text_parsed: Best thing to do, when the battle field seems like a near draw (but you know you have the advantage), take a while to think about declaring attackers. Maybe reach out like you're going to attack only to quickly pull your hand away. Then attack. Your opponent will think you're taking a risk and block-kill what creatures (s)he can (they'll think you've got nothing up your sleeve). Then, on your last main phase BAM! another turn! I guarantee this will work. 4/5 from me!

10622: Forced Retreat.author: tcollins
10622: Forced Retreat.text_parsed: Love the flavor text, can be used both offensively to return one of your opponent's creatures to the top of their library, or can be used defensively to allow one of your own creatures to be bounced back. (For example, bouncing a Wall of Roots back to the top of your library when it has four 0/-1 counters on it, allowing you to cast it again with no counters on it.)

10633: Warrior's Stand.author: OpeeFomenom
10633: Warrior's Stand.text_parsed:
Portal Three Kingdoms didn't have instants. It was meant as an introductory set so it took out things it thought would be too complicated for new players. These sorceries were essentially a gimmick to prepare new players for instants. It has the restriction, because, well, if it didn't, you would have to play it like a normal sorcery as opposed to a half instant.

It's an okay defensive card I suppose. Not much to really say on.

10636: Zodiac Ox.author: Zetan
10636: Zodiac Ox.text_parsed:
If you line these cards up in Chinese Zodiac order, starting with Snake, you get the following poem/story:

Thrice Xuande's ardent quest led to Nanyang,
Where Sleeping Dragon unveiled Han's partition:
‘First take Jingzhou, next the Riverlands;
On that rich region, base your own royal stand.'
Near death in Baidi, having reigned three years,
Bei sadly placed his son in Kongming's care.
By six offensives from the hills of Qi Kongming sought to change Han's destiny.
But the time of Han had run—could he Kongming not tell?—
That night his master star fell past the hills.
Jiang Wei alone still strove with might and main:
Nine times more he fought the north—in vain.
Zhong Hui and Deng Ai next led armies west:
And to the Cao, Han's hills and streams now passed.
Cao Pi, Cao Rui, Fang, Mao, and briefly, Huan—
The Sima took the empire in their turn.
Cao's abdication changed the face of all;
No mighty battles marked the Southland's fall.
Three kings no more—Chenliu, Guiming, Anle.
The fiefs and posts must now be filled anew.
The world's affairs rush on, an endless stream;
A sky-told fate, infinite in reach, dooms all.
The kingdoms three are now the stuff of dream,
For men to ponder, past all praise or blame.

They are all very mad at the wheat because Wheat deals 1 damage to all creatures during it's upkeep. But the saprolings all had som fancy shining lightning greaves equipped, so they can somehow attack the wheat the time they enter the battlefield. The saprolings are though being outmanned by Wheat, because Wheat brought his friends desert and That llama which wasn't printed, it's a complicated fight for the saprolings, but that's fine because they've also brought a friend: Twilight Shepherd, she ressurects them all, but that doesn't help, because now it's Wheats turn and that means 1 damage to ALL creatures.
This fight ended with only Twilight Shepherd and that llama which wasn't printed left on the battlefield, because Wheat had only ONE toughness point, so it fainted too. And deserts mom told him it was too late, so he had to go to bed...
Now's the epic fight between The Llama and Twilight Shepherd! But they both had 1 damage counter on them left because of Wheat, so they were too damaged so they couldn't fight.
With some fantasy, the game is even more magical! The art on this plains is a replica of the fight.

10728: Imperial Seal.author: TheKazu
10728: Imperial Seal.text_parsed:
This card has ONLY been printed in portal three kingdoms.
Portal three kingdoms, from my sources online had an "english print run smaller than beta." Take a moment to let that sink in. Beta had a print run of 7.3 million cards. Lets say, this has a print run of 7.3 million as well, though according to all sources it has "less" (though I have been unable to find one that gives an exact number).

This set has 10 cards per pack. So 730,000 packs were sold. Each one had 1 rare. So 730,000 total portal three kingdoms rares. There were 55 rares in the set. A total of 13.3k english legal copies of this card ever existed. Except less. Because the print run was less than that of beta. Keep in mind, that means there are more than 66% more black lotuses printed than this card. About three times more Libraries of Alexandria. This card and other non-reprinted portal rares are the rarest vintage-legal cards in the world.

All together now: 0_o!!!

(Also the card is practically a staple in any format its legal in, considering its about as good as demonic tutor.)

10732: Meng Huo, Barbarian King.author: patronofthesound
10732: Meng Huo, Barbarian King.text_parsed:
@ mike-c

Portal 3 kingdoms cards have the highest average price of any set. This is because the english print run of these cards was very minimal, probably only 500-1000 boxes or so. P3k is really more of a special set than a true expansion. The vast majority of extant cards from this set are in chinese or other eastern languages because it was an attempt to draw new players to the game from those regions. That's why the set is based on historical China. P3k cards are also pricey because they were printed 15 years ago, and are the only set on the plane of Earth. (Wizards has a rule about not setting cards on Earth now)
10732: Meng Huo, Barbarian King.text_posted:
